experiment: F-CON2 post-claim C-EDIT measurement — S352-S355 vs S351 baseline
expect: Post-claim C-EDIT overhead <=25% (vs 37.5% S351 baseline); claim.py reduces DUE-convergence events

method.baseline: S351 measurement: 8 observed commits, 3 wasted (CE-1 DUE-convergence on L-544 trimmed 3x independently). C-EDIT overhead = 37.5%.
method.classification: Each commit classified as productive, coordination, or C-EDIT overhead (wasted work repeating what another session did)

post_claim_s352_s355.ce1_detail: claim.py duplicate implementation (S352, 2 wasted) + L-574 overwrite->L-578 (S353, 1 wasted)
post_claim_s352_s355.ce4_detail: New collision type: sessions race for same lesson number. 0 wasted commits (sessions recover by choosing next number). ~30-60s recovery each.
post_claim_s352_s355.repair_harvest_note: All 6 are commit-by-proxy absorption (committing productive work from concurrent sessions), NOT wasted work

comparison.ce1_events_per_commit: 0.375 -> 0.044 (8.5x reduction per commit, at higher concurrency)
comparison.new_collision_type_ce4: lesson-slot contention emerged (8 events, 0 wasted commits, recovery cost only)
comparison.claim_tool_adoption: orient.py integration S355; workspace/claims/ active with 5 concurrent claims observed
confounds: Concurrency N>=5 (higher than baseline N>=3) — makes reduction MORE significant
S352 CE-1 events (claim.py + L-574) were BEFORE orient integration (S355) — early period inflates post-claim rate
Larger sample (45 vs 8 commits) gives more stable estimate

claim_tool_live_evidence.L601_prevented: L-601 claimed by concurrent session; this session redirected to L-602 — collision prevented in real-time
claim_tool_live_evidence.orient_integration: check_active_claims() in orient.py warns about concurrent claims at session start

actual: C-EDIT overhead 37.5% -> 6.7% (82% reduction). CE-1 DUE-convergence nearly eliminated. New CE-4 type (lesson-slot collision) emerged: 8 events, 0 wasted commits. claim.py prevents file-level collisions; lesson-number contention is the remaining gap.
diff: Expected <=25%, got 6.7% — exceeded expectation by 3.7x. CE-1 virtually eliminated. New CE-4 type was not predicted. claim.py's real-time prevention observed during this session (L-601 redirect).
f_con2_assessment: NEAR-RESOLVED. Tool built, integrated, measured. Remaining: (1) lesson-slot claiming protocol for CE-4; (2) maintenance.py GC hook. Both are incremental improvements, not blockers.
next: Wire claim.py GC into maintenance.py periodic; consider lesson-slot pre-claim (claim lesson number before writing); re-measure at S380.
